slug: /228
title: "This Week In React #228: React 19.1, Next.js deployment, React-Email, Triplex, Tinybase, Rspack, i18n-check, React-Admin | 0.79 Golden RC, ExecuTorch, Unistyles, Xcode 16.3, macOS, Screens, Gesture Handler | TypeScript, TC39, WebKit, Intl.Collator, Vitest 3.1"
authors: [matthieugicquel, cyrilbo]
date: 04-02-2025
---

segments.source_content: React 19.1 just dropped with better error handling and deeper integration for Server Components in Parcel. Meanwhile, Tailwind CSS 4.1 is right around the corner, and the community is buzzing with hot takes on CSS-in-JS. On the React Native side, the golden RC for 0.79 is out, and ExecuTorch v0.4.0 is landing soon with exciting AI features.

segments.source_content: For a decade, we navigated the complexities of disconnected systems, facing integration headaches and scaling challenges. Our journey to build effectively at scale led us to a breakthrough: [**Harmony**](https://bit.dev/blog/meet-harmony-a-practical-solution-for-composability/).

Discover our 10-year story of pioneering composable architecture and how Harmony finally delivered the monolithic simplicity and distributed power we always envisioned, transforming our development from struggle to exponential progress.
React 19.1 has been released this week, the most notable changes are:

- A new [`captureOwnerStack()`](https://react.dev/reference/react/captureOwnerStack) API that will be used by frameworks to provide better error information in dev. Itâ€™s different from the existing component stacks in how it handles `children` and DOM nodes.
- The â€œReact sideâ€ of Server Components support in Parcel, that works hand-in-hand with the new features in Parcel 2.14.
- An experimental `unstable_prerender()` for prerendering React Server Components on the server.

segments.source_content: This release also includes a slew of minor changes and fixes, most of them related to Server Components or `Suspense` boundaries.

- ğŸ’¸ [Strapi - Open-source headless Content Management, now with generous PaaS hosting, fully managed yet flexible and customizable. ](https://strapi.link/twir)
- ğŸ“œ [Is CSS-in-JS still a thing?](https://fullystacked.net/css-in-js-still-a-thing/) Itâ€™s not trendy anymore (at least not without a compiler to avoid the performance penalty) but itâ€™s still widely used.
- ğŸ“œ [Next.js Deployment Challenges: Why platforms need better open source collaboration](https://www.netlify.com/blog/how-we-run-nextjs/): Netlify explains why Next.js is complicated to deploy outside of Vercel (no adapter support, missing documentation, lack of visibilityâ€¦) and what they would like to change.
- ğŸ“œ [Adaptive Video Streaming With Dash.js In React](https://www.smashingmagazine.com/2025/03/adaptive-video-streaming-dashjs-react/): You probably wonâ€™t be building something like this every day, but it turns out adaptive streaming is not that complicated thanks to the DASH standard
- ğŸ“œ [i18n-check: End to end React i18n testing](https://lingual.dev/blog/i18n-check-end-to-end-react-i18n-testing/)
- ğŸ“œ [Keeping Costs in Check When Hosting Next.js on Vercel](https://www.thisdot.co/blog/keeping-costs-in-check-when-hosting-next-js-on-vercel)

- ğŸ“¦ [React-Admin 5.7](https://github.com/marmelab/react-admin/releases/tag/v5.7.0)

- ğŸ™ï¸ [This Month in React 2025-03: Next had an auth vulnerability, TypeScript is porting to Golang](https://creators.spotify.com/pod/show/reactiflux/episodes/TMiR-2025-03-Next-had-an-auth-vulnerability--TypeScript-is-porting-to-Golang-e30tvf5/a-abs3i7h)

segments.source_content: **[Ship dashboards in minutes â€” not sprints](https://semaphor.cloud)**
Sempahor is a React based SDK to launch fully-interactive dashboards in your customer-facing products.
Semaphor helps you decouple analytics from your product code, so you can iterate quickly, and ship new insights independently â€” without needing to redeploy your app.
The CPO of TalentsConnect sums it up best:

"Semaphor has transformed our product and data team's workflow. They can now more quickly prototype and test new use cases directly in our application with our clients, significantly reducing feedback cycle time. Plus, Semaphor's styling options are outstanding, fitting seamlessly with our product's design"

Itâ€™s been a quiet week in the React Native communityâ€”perhaps because all eyes are on the React Native Connection happening right now in Paris. Hopefully, weâ€™ll have plenty of exciting topics to dive into next week ğŸ¤—

- ğŸ—“ï¸ [App.js Conf](https://appjs.co/?utm_source=thisweekinreact) - ğŸ‡µğŸ‡± KrakÃ³w - 28-30 May. We're thrilled to announce the firstÂ speakers for App.js Conf 2025: Charlie Cheever,Â Enzo Manuel Mangano & Delphine Bugner! Grab your ticket now with a 15% discount using the code "TWIR".
- ğŸ“œ [SDK 52 patches for Xcode 16.3](https://expo.dev/changelog/xcode-16-3-patches): If you encountered build issues when upgrading to Xcode 16.3, you may have to install the latest SDK 52 patch and RN0.77. Or move back to Xcode 16.2 ğŸ« 
- ğŸ“œ [React Native: 10 years](https://shift.infinite.red/react-native-10-years-db9eb36c5af6): Infinite Red celebrates the birthday.
- ğŸ“¦ [React Native Screens 4.10](https://github.com/software-mansion/react-native-screens/releases/tag/4.10.0): iOS min supported version bumped to v15.1, experimental support for scrollview header when using formsheet, many android bug fixes.
- ğŸ“¦ [Unistyles 3.0 RC.1](https://github.com/jpudysz/react-native-unistyles/releases/tag/v3.0.0-rc.1): This has just been announced at React Native Connection conference, the library entered RC. Apart from the nice styling features, this version is quite exciting because it handles many things on the "Shadow Tree" of React Native using C++, allowing you to implement dynamic styles that do not need React to re-render components on the JS side when dependencies such as theme, signal, screen size/orientation and other dependencies change. This reminds how CSS works on the web: we don't need a React re-render when we cross a breakpoint.
- ğŸ“¦ [React Native MacOS 0.78](https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-macos/releases/tag/v0.78.0): The library caught up. We also heard it now supports Skia and WebGPU.
